text: Content Standard 1.0: Rules and Law: Students know why society needs rules, laws, and governments.

children.text: Rules and Law
Identify and follow class-room and school rules that guide behavior and establish order to accomplish tasks.
Identify examples of rules, laws, and authorities that keep people safe and property secure.
Describe the effects on society of the absence of law.
Explain the difference between the rule of law and the rule of man (such as divine right of monarchs, dictatorships).
Explain the concept of the rule of law in the establishment of the U.S. Constitution.
Documents
Identify the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution as written documents that are the foundation of the United States government.
Describe the significance of the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution as foundations of U.S. democracy.
Explain the influence of social contract theory, natural rights philosophy and republicanism in the Declaration of Independ-ence, the Articles of Con-federation, and the U.S. Constitution.

Describe the historic influ-ences on early U.S. documents, such as:
  • Greek law
  • Magna Carta
  • Iroquois League
Democratic Participation
Participate in class decision-making.
Explain that democracy involves voting, majority rule, and setting rules.
Describe the operation of representative govern-ment, including the rights of political minorities.
Explain popular sover-eignty and the need for citizen involvement at all levels of U.S. government.
Analyze the role of citizen participation in U.S. civic life.
The U.S. Constitution and Amendments
Describe how the U.S. Constitution serves as a device for preserving na-tional principles and as a vehicle for change, including knowledge of the formal process of amend-ing the U.S. Constitution.
Identify and explain changes in the interpretation and application of the U.S. Constitution.

text: Content Standard 2.0: The U.S. Government: Students know the United States Constitution and the government it creates.

children.text: The U.S. Constitution
Identify the three branches of government (as set forth in the U.S. Constitution).
Explain the functions of the three branches of gov-ernment (executive, legis-lative, and judicial) as found in the U.S. Constitution.
Examine the organization of the U.S. Constitution and describe the structure it creates, including the executive, legislative, and judicial branches.
The Legislative Structure and Process
Name the two houses of the U.S. Congress.
Explain the historic compromises that created a two-house Congress and identify the responsibilities of each.
Describe the creation of laws through the legislative process.
Legislative Powers
Identify the powers of the U.S. Congress, such as power to tax, declare war, and impeach the President.
Discuss enumerated and implied powers of the U.S. Congress.
Analyze and give examples of the expansion of the national government through the application of the enumerated and implied powers.
The Executive Branch
Name the current President of the United States.
Identify the duties of the President.
Describe the duties of the President, such as presenting a budget proposal.

Describe the duties of the executive branch, including:
  • Cabinet/departments (W)
  • regulatory commissions (W)
  • White House staff (W)
The Judicial Branch
Identify the Supreme Court as the highest court in the land.

List the ways the Supreme Court determines policy, including:
  • judicial review
  • interpreting laws
  • overruling or revising its previous decisions
Describe the structure and jurisdiction of the federal court system and analyze the power of judicial review.
The Jury System
Describe the purpose of a judge and jury in a trial as it relates to resolving disputes.
Describe the trial process, including the selection and responsibilities of jurors.
Explain the importance of the jury process in a democratic society.
Checks and Balances
Explain the system of checks and balances in the design of the U.S. Constitution.
Analyze the effectiveness of checks and balances in maintaining the equal division of power.

text: Content Standard 3.0: National and State Government: Students can explain the relationship between the states and national government.

children.text: Division of Powers
Give examples of gov-ernmental powers (such as the power to tax, declare war, and issue drivers' licenses) that are dis-tributed between the state and national governments.
Explain the U.S. Consti-tutional provisions for division of powers between the state and national governments (delegated, reserved, concurrent powers).
Federalism
Define "federalism."
Provide contemporary examples of federalism.
Constitutional Supremacy
Explain how the suprem-acy clause of the U.S. Constitution defines the relationship between state and national governments.
Use examples to illustrate the supremacy clause in defining the relationship between state and national governments.

text: Content Standard 4.0: The Political Process: Students describe the roles of political parties, interest groups, and public opinion in the democratic process.

children.text: Leaders and Elections
List the qualities of a leader.
Describe the election process.
Assess the processes by which leaders are selected in the U.S. political system and analyze the role of the electoral college system in the election of the President.
Political Parties
Name the two major political parties.
Provide examples of how political parties changed.
Analyze the roles and function of factions within political parties and the role of parties in public policy and politics.
Interest Groups
Discuss why people form groups.
Give examples of interest groups.
Identify the impact of interest groups on the political process.
Evaluate the significance of interest groups in the political process of a democratic society.
Formation of Public Opinion
Identify sources of information people use to form an opinion.
Identify the influence of the media in forming public opinion.
Analyze the role that television and other media play in the process of political persuasion.
Propaganda
Identify propaganda and persuasion in political advertising and literature.
Evaluate propaganda in both historic and current political communication.
Public Policy
Provide examples of contemporary public issues that may require public solutions.
Describe the process by which public policy is formed and carried out.

text: Content Standard 5.0: Citizenship: Students know the roles, rights, and responsibilities of United States citizens and the symbols of our country.

children.text: Citizenship
Recognize the Pledge of Allegiance.
Describe the difference between a natural-born and a naturalized citizen of the United States.
Identify the rights, privi-leges, and responsibilities associated with U.S. citi-zenship, including voting, holding office, jury duty, or military, community, or public service.
Examine the rights of citizens and how these rights may be restricted.
Examine the responsibilities of U.S. citizens.
Symbols
Name a traditional U.S. patriotic activity, holiday, or symbol, such as the Fourth of July.
Explain why we have patriotic holidays.
Describe the symbolic importance of the Fourth of July and the Pledge of Allegiance.

Explain the significance of mottoes and symbols including:
  • E Pluribus Unum
  • National Anthem
  • Flag
  • Statue of Liberty
  • Great Seal
  • Oath of office
  • Pledge of Allegiance
Explain symbols and documents of a nation and how they represent its identity.
Individual Rights
Identify an individual's rights within the classroom.
Identify the Bill of Rights.
Explain the necessity of the Bill of Rights for a democratic society.
Describe the development of the Bill of Rights and provide a contemporary application.
Analyze the United States Constitution and its amendments in protecting individual rights, including the Fourteenth Amendment's provisions for due process and equal protection.
Conflict and Resolution
Identify conflicts in the school and discuss peaceful resolution.
Identify ways conflicts can be resolved in a peaceful manner that respects individual rights.
Identify examples of con-flict resolution that respect individual rights at school and in the community, within the United States.
Identify major conflicts in social, political, and economic life and analyze the role of compromise in the resolution of these issues.
The Supreme Court and Individual Rights Cases

Describe the role of the United States Supreme Court as guardian of in-dividual rights through the examination of landmark cases, including:
  • Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka
  • Gideon v. Wainwright
  • Miranda v. Arizona
  • Tinker v. Des Moines Independent Community School District

text: Content Standard 6.0: State and Local Government: Students know the structure and functions of state and local governments.

children.text: Structure of State, Local, and Tribal Government
Name the current governor of Nevada.
Explain why local governments are created within states.
Name the three branches of state government.
Compare the organization and purpose of state, local, and tribal government.
Explain the structure and function of state and local governments.
Describe the unique role of tribal governments within the United States.
Compare and contrast the structure of the Nevada and United States Constitutions.
Court Systems
Know that there are different types of courts.
Describe the juvenile, civil, and criminal court systems.
Describe the differences between the local, state, and federal court systems.

text: Content Standard 7.0: Political and Economic Systems: Students explain the different political and economic systems in the world.

children.text: Comparative Political Systems

List the characteristics of a nation-state, including:
  • self-rule
  • territory
  • population
  • organized government

Define the world's major political systems, including:
  • monarchy
  • totalitarian dictatorship
  • presidential system
  • communism

Summarize and evaluate the significant characteristics of the world's major political systems, including:
  • monarchy
  • totalitarian dictatorship
  • presidential system
  • parliamentary system
  • communism
Comparative Economic Systems

Define the world's major economic systems, including:
  • capitalism
  • mixed economy
  • socialism
  • command economy

Define and analyze the major economic systems of the world, including:
  • capitalism
  • mixed economy
  • socialism
  • command economy

text: Content Standard 8.0: International Relations: Students know the political and economic relationship of the United States and its citizens to other nations.

children.text: From Individual to the World
Name their school and community.
Identify their county, state, and country.
Identify the countries bordering the United States.
Identify nations that play a significant role in U.S. foreign policy.
Analyze the conflict between U.S. policies of isolationism versus intervention in world affairs.
Foreign Policy
Explain ways in which nations interact.

Define foreign policy and describe ways nations in-teract diplomatically, including:
  • treaties
  • trade
  • humanitarian aid
  • military intervention

Identify and analyze the effectiveness of U.S. foreign policy in dealing with international problems and concerns including:
  • diplomacy
  • economic policy
  • humanitarian aid
  • military intervention
International Organizations
Describe the purpose of the United Nations.
List and describe non-gov-ernmental international organizations, such as the World Bank, Amnesty International, and the International Red Cross.
Critique the role of international organizations, such as the United Nations and non-governmental organizations, in world affairs.
